text: thread for air pollution data- add the data source(s) you have selected and answer some of the questions in this thread - be prepared to talk about your chosen data source

elements.text: thread for air pollution data- add the data source(s) you have selected and answer some of the questions in this thread - be prepared to talk about your chosen data source

text:
<https://openweathermap.org/api/air-pollution>


• data format is JSON
• data looks clean and would probably not need more than a simple parsing to turn the strings into numbers and outlier removal
• JSON is pretty simple and could be merged with other data sources without too much effort
• one could answer any questions about numerical state of the weather at any geographic point on the planet and categorical questions could be derived from numerical values with a bit of programming
• one could gain concrete knowledge about pollution levels at each point and find correlations between the weather state on different points on the globe and build forecasting models
• as an example: being able to forecast an upcoming increase in pollution levels of a certain substance beyond harmful levels may enable us to take necessary measures to mitigate the damage
• one could easily imagine a system that is fed the weather info through the abovementioned api and dispatches "warning events" based on domain metrics to institutions that are qualified to take action

attachments.title: Air Pollution - OpenWeatherMap
attachments.text: Air Pollution API provides current, forecast and historical air pollution data for any coordinates on the globe. Besides basic Air Quality Index, the API returns data about polluting gases, such as Carbon monoxide (CO), Nitrogen monoxide (NO), Nitrogen dioxide (NO2), Ozone (O3), Sulphur dioxide (SO2), Ammonia (NH3), and particulates (PM2.5 and PM10).

text: I think the data referenced in this paper could be interesting, it contains pollution emission and pollution exposure data in the period 2000-2017 and it is desegregated by cities, or I think so, as I've spent half an hour waiting for the file to open to no avail <https://enveurope.springeropen.com/articles/10.1186/s12302-020-00450-2#Sec2>

attachments.title: Urban population exposure to air pollution in Europe over the last decades
attachments.text: Background The paper presents an overview of air quality in the 27 member countries of the European Union (EU) and the United Kingdom (previous EU-28), from 2000 to 2017. We reviewed the progress made towards meeting the air quality standards established by the EU Ambient Air Quality Directives (European Council Directive 2008/50/EC) and the World Health Organization (WHO) Air Quality Guidelines by estimating the trends (Mann-Kendal test) in national emissions of main air pollutants, urban population exposure to air pollution, and in mortality related to exposure to ambient fine particles (PM2.5) and tropospheric ozone (O3). Results Despite significant reductions of emissions (e.g., sulfur oxides: ~ 80%, nitrogen oxides: ~ 46%, non-methane volatile organic compounds: ~ 44%, particulate matters with a diameter lower than 2.5 µm and 10 µm: ~ 30%), the EU-28 urban population was exposed to PM2.5 and O3 levels widely exceeding the WHO limit values for the protection of human health. Between 2000 and 2017, the annual PM2.5-related number of deaths decreased (- 4.85 per 106 inhabitants) in line with a reduction of PM2.5 levels observed at urban air quality monitoring stations. The rising O3 levels became a major public health issue in the EU-28 cities where the annual O3-related number of premature deaths increased (+ 0.55 deaths per 106 inhabitants). Conclusions To achieve the objectives of the Ambient Air Quality Directives and mitigate air pollution impacts, actions need to be urgently taken at all governance levels. In this context, greening and re‐naturing cities and the implementation of fresh air corridors can help meet air quality standards, but also answer to social needs, as recently highlighted by the COVID-19 lockdowns.
attachments.fallback: Environmental Sciences Europe: Urban population exposure to air pollution in Europe over the last decades

(air pollution levels now in BCN and a prevision for the next 6 days) <https://www.iqair.com/es/spain/catalunya/barcelona>
(max and min levels registered per day) <https://aqicn.org/city/barcelona/>
(the different substances or measures on air like PM2.5, PM10, O3, NO2) <https://aqicn.org/scale/>
(the different stations in the city: University area, Sants, Eixample, Gràcia, and more) <https://ajuntament.barcelona.cat/qualitataire/en/qualitat-de-laire/com-es-lluita-contra-la-contaminacio/atmospheric-pollution-monitoring-and>

(a scientific article about premature mortality related to air pollution in BCN) file:///C:/Users/isaac/Downloads/ijerph-15-02405.pdf

attachments.title: Atmospheric pollution monitoring and forecasting network
attachments.text: 11 stations make up the Atmospheric Pollution Monitoring and Forecasting Network measuring the air concentration of the main environmental pollutants in places that represent different street categories. We explain you how the pollutants are measured and how to interpret the real-time five level classification.

text: <https://aqicn.org/data-platform/register/>

Air quality in London: <https://www.londonair.org.uk/LondonAir/Default.aspx>

Data format: CSV
Cleaning: Some irrelevant columns could be removed
Joining with other sources: Data is based on monitoring stations, so could potentially be joined with other sources that use the same data
Reliability of data: Site managed by an official source (maintained by Imperial College London)
Data question examples: 
• What is the average air quality in London?
• When and where in London is the air quality the highest/lowest?
• What are risk areas with lower than average air quality?
• What type of pollutants can be measured?

elements.text: Air quality in London:

Joining with other sources: Data is based on monitoring stations, so could potentially be joined with other sources that use the same data

attachments.title: World Development Indicators | DataBank
attachments.text: World Development Indicators (WDI) is the primary World Bank collection of development indicators, compiled from officially recognized international sources. It presents the most current and accurate global development data available, and includes national, regional and global estimates. [Note: Even though Global Development Finance (GDF) is no longer listed in the WDI database name, all external debt and financial flows data continue to be included in WDI. The GDF publication has been renamed International Debt Statistics (IDS), and has its own separate database, as well.
